content.webTitle: Steven Gerrard shows his knack for attack is still working for Liverpool

fields.headline: Steven Gerrard shows his knack for attack is still working for Liverpool
fields.bodyText: There is life in Steven Gerrard yet. The Liverpool captain was not on the scoresheet against West Bromwich Albion but he completed his third game in a week, confounding those who thought his 34-year-old legs might be in need of more rest this season. Gerrard said after his goal in the Merseyside derby last week it was nice to prove a point to people who had been prematurely writing him off, though that goal was from a set piece. He has been playing in a more withdrawn role as a defensive midfielder yet Brendan Rodgers believes he can still contribute in a more forward role if necessary, and could even be the key to producing the best from Mario Balotelli. The Liverpool manager encouraged his captain to do just that towards the end of the 2-1 victory at Anfield, and even suggested he might get a start in an attacking role before long. “If I thought it would help the team I could do that,” Rodgers said. “You could see his quality and his ability to combine with Balotelli straight away. Steven is a player who makes the game look simple and Mario knows he is playing with one of the greats of the game. Mario is a guy who needs certain type of passes and Steven is the sort of player who can provide them. “He definitely added something to our game in that position, though I feel he has been outstanding in the deeper position too. It was refreshing to see the cleverness and brightness he brought, and that was his third tough game in a week.” There were two other members of the Gerrard fan club present on Merseyside on Saturday, his former manager Gérard Houllier and the West Bromwich manager Alan Irvine. “I was chatting to Gérard after the game and we both found ourselves taking about Steven Gerrard,” Irvine said. “Obviously he knows him very well but we both think he is still a terrific player. Wherever he plays he is still a key player for Liverpool, and anyone who thinks his legs have gone needs to have a look at the time he chased Cristian Gamboa down the wing and stayed with him. That took some doing, so I am not having it that he is finished. He has been a great player for many years and will continue to be for some time yet.” Making his debut for West Brom at right-back in place of the ineligible Andre Wisdom, Gamboa was one of the small successes for West Brom. Saido Berahino was another, and West Brom could conceivably have taken something from the game had he converted one of his first-half chances to put them in front. “Even at his very best he will still miss a few,” Irvine said. “That’s part of being a striker. Saido knows he needs to improve on his heading too, but he’s fine. He’s got a fantastic approach and great enthusiasm and he’ll get better as a finisher as time goes on.” As it was Berahino scored from the penalty spot to equalise Adam Lallana’s opening goal after Dejan Lovren had brought him down on the edge of the box – actually outside the area as both managers accepted when they saw the replays – but West Brom were level for only four minutes until Jordan Henderson sidefooted in with Raheem Sterling still appealing for a penalty for a shove by Craig Gardner. Only then was Balotelli introduced from the bench, curtailing a frustrating match for Rickie Lambert, who must have been envious at seeing Lallana get off the mark with his first Liverpool goal. Despite Gerrard’s best efforts when Philippe Coutinho came off for Lucas Leiva, Liverpool could not add to their lead, though West Brom’s organisation deserves some of the credit for that. Liverpool were not at their best, with Sterling and Coutinho only fitfully contributing, but the visitors were much improved on the side who struggled so badly towards the end of last season. “Raheem will always give 100%,” Rodgers said of his England forward. “He does his best, but from time to time he will have games where he doesn’t set the world alight. His next contract is not a big issue for us. We know he is happy here, his agent understands that he is in the perfect place, so everything is calm. No one is thinking of anything other than Raheem continuing to play for Liverpool. Ian Ayre has spoken with his representatives and he is quite relaxed.” Man of the match Jordan Henderson (Liverpool)
